briefdescription.para: enables the subflow to join its parent task

detaileddescription.para: Performs an immediate action to join the subflow. Once the subflow is joined, it is considered finished and you may not modify the subflow anymore.
Only the worker that spawns this subflow can join it.

briefdescription.para: enables the subflow to detach from its parent task

detaileddescription.para: Performs an immediate action to detach the subflow. Once the subflow is detached, it is considered finished and you may not modify the subflow anymore.
Only the worker that spawns this subflow can detach it.

briefdescription.para: resets the subflow to a clean graph of joinable state

detaileddescription.para: Resetting a subflow will first clear the underlying task dependency graphs and then change the subflow to a joinable state.

briefdescription.para: queries if the subflow is joinable

detaileddescription.para: This member function queries if the subflow is joinable. When a subflow is joined or detached, it becomes not joinable.

F
callable type
ArgsT
parameter types
f
callable object to call
args
parameters to pass to the callable
a tf::Future that will holds the result of the execution The method creates an asynchronous task to launch the given function on the given arguments. The difference to tf::Executor::async is that the created asynchronous task pertains to the subflow. When the subflow joins, all asynchronous tasks created from the subflow are guaranteed to finish before the join. For example:
This method is thread-safe and can be called by multiple tasks in the subflow at the same time.

simplesect.para: You cannot create asynchronous tasks from a detached subflow. Doing this results in undefined behavior.

briefdescription.para: runs the given function asynchronously and assigns the task a name

detaileddescription.para:
F
callable type
ArgsT
parameter types
name
name of the asynchronous task
f
callable object to call
args
parameters to pass to the callable
a tf::Future that will holds the result of the execution The method creates a named asynchronous task to launch the given function on the given arguments. The difference from tf::Executor::async is that the created asynchronous task pertains to the subflow. When the subflow joins, all asynchronous tasks created from the subflow are guaranteed to finish before the join. For example:
This method is thread-safe and can be called by multiple tasks in the subflow at the same time.

simplesect.para: You cannot create named asynchronous tasks from a detached subflow. Doing this results in undefined behavior.

briefdescription.para: similar to tf::Subflow::async but does not return a future object

detaileddescription.para: This member function is more efficient than tf::Subflow::async and is encouraged to use when there is no data returned.

briefdescription.para: similar to tf::Subflow::named_async but does not return a future object

detaileddescription.para: This member function is more efficient than tf::Subflow::named_async and is encouraged to use when there is no data returned.

briefdescription.para: returns the executor that runs this subflow
returns the worker that spawns this subflow
class to construct a subflow graph from the execution of a dynamic task

detaileddescription.para: By default, a subflow automatically joins its parent node. You may explicitly join or detach a subflow by calling tf::Subflow::join or tf::Subflow::detach, respectively. The following example creates a taskflow graph that spawns a subflow from the execution of task B, and the subflow contains three tasks, B1, B2, and B3, where B3 runs after B1 and B2.
